qas.question: What shows support for the separation of church and state as early as the mid-17th century?
What were the Remonstrance opposed to?
When did a group of English citizens sign a document condemning hatred, war and bondage?
Who were the signers of the document affronted by the persecution of?
What had Peter Stuyvesant formally banned all of other than the Dutch Reformed Church?
What shows support for the separation of church and state as late as the mid-17th century?
What were the Remonstrance not opposed to?
When did a group of English citizens reject a document condemning hatred, war and bondage?
Who were the rejecters of the document affronted by the persecution of?

context: <a0_0><b5_0>The Flushing Remonstrance<b5_0/><a0_0/> shows support for separation of church and state as early as the mid-17th century, stating their opposition to <a1_0><b6_0>religious persecution<b6_0/> of any sort<a1_0/>: "The law of love, peace and liberty in the states extending to Jews, Turks and Egyptians, as they are considered sons of Adam, which is the glory of the outward state of Holland, so love, peace and liberty, extending to all in Christ Jesus, condemns hatred, war and bondage." The document was signed <a2_0><b7_0>December 27, 1657<b7_0/><a2_0/> by a group of English citizens in America who were affronted by persecution of <a3_0>Quakers<a3_0/> and the religious policies of the Governor of New Netherland, Peter Stuyvesant. Stuyvesant had formally banned all <a4_0><b9_0>religions<b9_0/><a4_0/> other than the Dutch Reformed Church from being practiced in the colony, in accordance with the laws of the Dutch Republic. The signers indicated their "desire therefore in this case not to judge lest we be judged, neither to condemn least we be condemned, but rather let every man stand or fall to his own Master." Stuyvesant fined the petitioners and threw them in prison until they recanted. However, John Bowne allowed the <b8_0>Quakers<b8_0/> to meet in his home. Bowne was arrested, jailed, and sent to the Netherlands for trial; the Dutch court exonerated Bowne.
